author: Meymo
body: This is a sensationalist post that indicates you invest one time only and never again. You would blow the SPY away if you invest while the market is going down. This is true in almost every instance, even on things like Akamai, which had a 99.75% drawdown. If you would keep investing, you end up [way ahead](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=100000&annualOperation=1&annualAdjustment=1000&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=2&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=AKAM&allocation1_1=100) in the long run. The lesson from this is to invest and keep investing. Treat your investments like bills and pay them every month. That way, you’re capturing the upside and downside.

author: FinndBors
body:
They manage a bunch of mini-datacenters on the "edge" -- over 200 of them. They also have "anycast" capability, which allows them to route requests to the nearest edge server. This allows them to do many things.

The most simplest use case for this is a CDN, where you put your big images, videos, etc. so you don't have to use heavy bandwidth over the internet. Latency is also improved. Cloudflare is not the only player here, the one of the oldest and biggest in this space is Akamai which was one of the high flying tech stocks of the dot com boom.

Another is edge computing. Think of the capability of running some code at the edge servers to minimize the load on your central servers running on AWS or Google or your own datacenter.

Another is DDOS security. The edge servers will initially take requests to a website. If it is under attack, it will require the client to do some hard math problem before forwarding the request to the actual website. This way the actual website won't be bombarded with requests, and bots need to have a lot more computing power to be able to affect a site.

There are a number of other things such as VPN, etc. that they can run on top of this infrastructure. See https://www.cloudflare.com/ products for detail.

author: aske999
body:
Coming from the software side, they essentially are the highways of America. Think about how we transport goods in the context of roads. Usually there are the big highways that everyone shares and uses. However on the internet, nothing is stopping people from building their own roads except the cost, upkeep, and protection of the roads they built which can quickly spiral out of control.

Now imagine that there are companies that builds and privatizes their own roads. This is where CDNs like cloudflare come in. Want to get around a traffic jam? Some people will pay an arbitrary amount use your private road to bypass the jam and clouflare will serve them. They can also provide security and other amenities along their roads. The name of the game is scalability and presence here which takes a large amount of time to build up.

CDNs like cloudflare have good reputations and show little sign of stopping. You could look into Akamai to see a bigger player. Overall its an extremely safe stock considering the people behind it are really really good at their jobs.
